questions.text: 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided abdominal pain and blood in his urine. Physical examination shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side. Microscopic examination of the urine is shown below. Further laboratory evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following abnormalities in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Aminoaciduria

questions.text: Which of the following regions contain only thick filaments and no thin filaments?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E

 

In the image of the skeletal muscle sarcomere, region E corresponds to the H-zone, which contains only thick filaments (myosin) and no thin filaments (actin). The H-zone is found in the center of the A-band, and thin filaments do not overlap this region, distinguishing it from other sarcomere zones

 

  • A: Z line (Z disc) boundary between adjacent sarcomeres
  • B: I band – contains only thin filaments (actin)
  • C: M line – center of the sarcomere, where thick filaments are anchored
  • D: A band – entire length of thick filaments; includes regions of overlap with thin filaments
  • E: H zone – area with only thick filaments (myosin), no thin filaments

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for persistent lower back pain and fatigue. Laboratory testing shows anemia and renal dysfunction. Serum electrophoresis of the serum proteins is shown below. A medication that blocks cellular proteasome action is administered. This treatment is most likely to cause which of the following effects on the abnormal cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased apoptosis 

 

The patient's findings (persistent back pain, anemia, renal dysfunction) and the serum protein electrophoresis image showing a prominent gamma spike (M protein) are classic for multiple myeloma.

 

Proteasome inhibitors (like bortezomib) are used to treat multiple myeloma. They block the proteasome pathway, causing accumulation of misfolded proteins, which triggers cellular stress and leads to increased apoptosis of the malignant plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Augmented cytotoxic T-cell response: Not the main effect of proteasome inhibition in multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Decreased DNA methylation and Option C. Impaired RNA splicing: Not the mechanism targeted by proteasome inhibitors.

 

Therefore, treatment with a proteasome inhibitor causes increased apoptosis of abnormal myeloma cells.

questions.text: 34-year-old man is evaluated in the clinic due to difficulty walking over the past 2 weeks. His symptoms have resulted in several recent falls. The physician asks him to stand with his feet close together, arms to the sides, and eyes closed. This maneuver most likely tests for abnormalities in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proprioception

 

  • The described maneuver is the Romberg test, which evaluates dorsal column function (position sense). Worsening sway with eyes closed indicates impaired proprioception.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Cortical sensory integration: Tested by stereognosis, graphesthesia, and two-point discrimination (parietal cortex), not by Romberg.


Option B. Gait: Assessed by observing walking patterns (e.g., tandem gait), not by standing feet together with eyes closed.


Option C. Motor coordination: Cerebellar coordination is checked with finger-to-nose or heel-to-shin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office due to exertional dyspnea. The patient has a history of lgA nephropathy; she received hemodialysis for 2 years before undergoing kidney transplantation last month. Chest x-ray reveals cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Further evaluation determines that her symptoms are likely due to persistence of the arteriovenous fistula that was used for hemodialysis. Which of the following physiologic changes in 1) cardiac output, 2) systemic vascular resistance and 3) venous return respectively are present in this patient due to the fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increases, decreases, increases

 

  • Cardiac output increases because an arteriovenous (AV) fistula creates a low-resistance pathway, causing more blood to flow from arteries to veins directly. This increases venous return to the heart, which in turn increases cardiac output by the Frank-Starling mechanism.
  • Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) decreases due to the low resistance pathway created by the fistula; blood bypasses the high-resistance arteriolar bed and returns quickly to the venous system, lowering overall SVR.
  • Venous return increases because the fistula allows blood to flow directly into the venous system, increasing preload and venous return.

 

Thus, the AV fistula leads to increased cardiac output and venous return but decreased systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to confusion and lethargy. The patient was asymptomatic when her husband left for work in the morning, but when he arrived home, he found her in bed weak and disoriented. The patient's medical conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which she takes multiple medications.  Laboratory testing shows an elevated serum C-peptide level. If her current condition is due to an antidiabetic drug, which of the following is the most likely culprit agent?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Glyburide

questions.text: The combined compliance of the lung and chest wall of a healthy individual is measured and plotted as shown below. It is noted that the intrapleural pressure at the end of maximal inspiration is -8 cm H20 (marked x). Which of the following is the best estimate of the intrapleural pressure at the point marked by the black dot?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) -5cm H20

 

At the point marked by the black dot, which represents normal end-expiratory or functional residual capacity (FRC), the intrapleural pressure is approximately -5 cm H₂O. This negative pressure keeps the lung expanded and prevents collapse.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. +10 cm H₂O: This would indicate a highly positive pressure, which does not occur physiologically within the pleural space.

 

Option B. +5 cm H₂O: Pleural pressure is not positive in normal respiratory physiology at FRC.

 

Option D. 0 cm H₂O: Occurs with tension pneumothorax or lung collapse, not at equilibrium in a healthy individual.

choices.text: Myocardial hypertrophy and fibrosis due to uncontrolled hypertension
Myocardial infiltration by mature lymphocytes

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is hospitalized due to chest pressure and shortness of breath. Two days ago her husband died in a car accident.  ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversions in the anterior leads. Echocardiogram shows hypokinesis of the apical wall with decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Diagnostic coronary angiography shows no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease.  Which of the following is the likely cause of this patient's initial presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Catecholamine-induced myocardial stunning

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe headache. The patient describes unbearable, throbbing pain around his right eye that awakened him. Over the past week, he has had several similar episodes, which spontaneously resolved after 20-30 minutes. On physical examination, he appears restless and paces in the room. There is mild conjunctival injection and miosis of the right eye. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cluster headache

questions.text: Physicians conduct a series of animal experiments to determine pulmonary tissue regeneration capacity. During one of the experiments, lung alveoli are exposed to NO2 and massive necrosis of the epithelial lining ensues. Histologic examination of the injured tissues a month later shows partial recovery of the alveolar epithelial lining. This regenerated tissue is most likely derived from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Label B marks type II pneumocytes, which function as the stem cells of the alveolar epithelium. After injury, type II pneumocytes proliferate and differentiate into type I pneumocytes, regenerating the alveolar lining and restoring epithelial integrity.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. A: Type I pneumocytes—flattened cells involved in gas exchange and cannot regenerate the epithelium.

 

Option C. C: Alveoli represented by empty air filled space

 

Option D. D: Capillary endothelial cells, play a role in gas exchange but not in epithelial regeneration.

choices.text: Low renin, low aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
Low renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
Low renin, low aldosterone, low angiotensin II, high potassium

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the OPD due to increasing headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is significant for a transient ischemic attack that led to a right carotid endarterectomy 5 years ago. Blood pressure is 220/120 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min. Bilateral abdominal bruits are present. Blood testing in this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium

 

Bilateral renal artery stenosis → secondary hyperaldosteronism with RAAS activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low renin, low aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium: Not stenosis.

 

Option C. Low renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium: Not possible here.

 

Option D. Low renin, low aldosterone, low angiotensin II, high potassium: Hyporeninemic states.

questions.text: 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain, nausea, and confusion. She has no significant past medical history and does not use tobacco or alcohol as they have made her feel sick in the past.  A sample of her urine is reddish in color and darkens on standing for 24 hours. Intravenous dextrose is administered, and her symptoms improve significantly. Dextrose infusion most likely improved this patient's condition by affecting which of the following pathways?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Porphyrin synthesis

questions.text: 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation comes to the office due to numbness of his left hand for the past 3 weeks. When the eyes are closed, he is unable to recognize the letters written on his left hand with a stylus. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Gait is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following locations of the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The finding of astereognosis (inability to recognize objects or letters by touch, despite normal strength and sensation otherwise) with a history of atrial fibrillation suggests a stroke affecting the contralateral primary somatosensory cortex in the parietal lobe.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • Astereognosis: Characteristic of lesions involving the primary somatosensory cortex, specifically the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.
  • Normal motor function, reflexes, gait: Rules out motor cortex, cerebellum, or brainstem involvement.
  • Atrial fibrillation: Risk factor for embolic stroke.
  • Left hand involvement points to right hemisphere lesion (by brain symmetry; image is a left lateral brain, but answer is based on the cortex’s role)

questions.text: Physiologists conduct a series of experiments on hypophysectomized animals to investigate the effects of cortisol on vascular reactivity. Their initial tests show that administration of cortisol alone does not elicit a vascular response. Next, the researchers measure vascular reactivity to an infusion of norepinephrine both with and without pretreatment with cortisol. The results of their experiments are shown in the graph below. Which of the following pharmacologic principles best describes the effect of cortisol in this experiment?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Permisiveness

questions.text: Special electrodes are used to detect the change in membrane potential of a specific type of cardiac cell. These changes are recorded on the graph below. The deflection indicated by the arrow is most likely caused by movement of which of the following ions?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Calcium

choices.text: Increased estrogen effect on the pituitary
Inhibition of gonadotropin-releasing hormone secretion

questions.text: 29-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the office due to a 2-month history of worsening bilateral nipple discharge. Her last menstrual period was 3 months ago, and home pregnancy tests have been negative.  On physical examination, visual fields are intact. Brain imaging shows a 0.6-cm pituitary mass. Pharmacotherapeutic treatment is begun, and on a follow-up visit the patient reports that her symptoms are improving. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Stimulation of pituitary dopamine receptors

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation and shortness of breath. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard and on examination, a prominent ’a’ wave on JVP was found. What is the most appropriate diagnosis among the following options?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Tricuspid Stenosis

questions.text: A patient has hyperkalemia, raised uric acid levels and is going through hemodialysis. While this, patient develops drowsiness, had a seizure and got hypotensive. What can be given in treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic, used to reduce cerebral edema in dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nesiritide: BNP analog for CHF, not here.

 

Option C. Ethacrynic acid: Loop diuretic, not first choice.

 

Option D. Bumetanide: Loop diuretic, not used here.

questions.text: 42-year-old man is hospitalized with fever and persistent sore throat. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.3°C (101 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 16/min. There are several bruises on his trunk, and blood is oozing from his intravenous catheter venipuncture sites. His blood fibrinogen level is 110 mg/dL (normal 150-400 mg/dL). Bone marrow biopsy is shown here. Chromosomal analysis of these immature cells is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution: Ans. D. t (15;17)

questions.text: 23-year-old man undergoes exercise physiology testing. He jogs on a treadmill to achieve a moderate-intensity physical activity level based on a target heart rate of 50%-70% of his estimated maximum heart rate. An increase in which of the following is expected at the peak of his exertion?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Venous blood mean CO2 content

choices.text: DCT, secretion of hydrogen ions
Collecting duct, secretion of hydrogen ions

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the OPD due to poor weight gain and frequent urination. His weight percentile has decreased from 60th percentile to 10th percentile, consistent with failure to thrive. Physical examination reveals frontal bossing. He is found to have glucosuria on urinalysis, although his serum glucose is within normal limits. Additional serum laboratory studies reveal hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following structure/function combinations is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. PCT, reabsorption of bicarbonate

choices.text: Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells
Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase-stimulated cells
Splenic hyperactivity with cell trapping by the reticuloendothelial system
Ineffective hematopoiesis secondary to micronutrient deficiency

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman come to the emergency department due to bloody stools. For the past month, she has also had decreased energy.  Skin examination shows pallor and scattered bruises in various stages of healing throughout the trunk. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Complete blood count results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 um³

 

Platelets: 10,000/mm²

 

Leukocytes: 1050/mm³

 

Neutrophils: 5%

 

Lymphocytes: 95%

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patients condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells

 

  • The patient presents with pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia), bruising, and bleeding, which suggests bone marrow failure.
  • The normal MCV and lack of organomegaly argue against micronutrient deficiency or splenic sequestration.
  • The finding of severe leukopenia with lymphocyte predominance supports an immune-mediated process.
  • Aplastic anemia is caused by autoimmune destruction or suppression of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells, resulting in pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase-stimulated cells: Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase cells occurs in chronic myeloid leukemia, which doesn’t present with pancytopenia and lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Splenic hyperactivity with cell trapping by the reticuloendothelial system: Splenic hyperactivity causes cytopenias but is usually associated with splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Ineffective hematopoiesis secondary to micronutrient deficiency: Micronutrient deficiency leads to ineffective hematopoiesis but usually causes macrocytosis or other characteristic blood changes.

questions.text: Neurophysiologists are studying recordings of the membrane potential from a giant squid axon. A portion of their recordings is shown on the slide below. The membrane is most permeable to potassium ions at which of the following points?
questions.solution: Ans. C) D

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes an elective surgery under general anesthesia. Two hours into the surgery, his left ventricular pressure-volume loop has changed from the solid line to the dashed line, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's hemodynamic change?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Normal saline infusion

questions.text: 60-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to difficulty climbing stairs and dyspnea on exertion over the last 6 weeks. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Skin examination shows scattered ecchymoses. Laboratory results show mild hyperglycemia and elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol. Serum cortisol level is at the upper limit of normal and is not suppressed following administration of low-dose dexamethasone. Serum ACTH level is elevated. Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe lung mass. Which of the following changes are most likely to occur after administration of high-dose dexamethasone in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. No change in cortisol

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimen of a patient is shown below along with the microscopy. The report shows mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, and low sugars. Which of the following is the likely etiology?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Tuberculous meningitis

questions.solution: Ans. B. Omapatrilat

questions.solution: Ans. B. Viral load

questions.solution: Ans. D. Sodium bicarbonate

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.
The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Besides being an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), losartan also has properties as a thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits platelet aggregation, contributing to its cardiovascular protective effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Usually telmisartan dose should be adjusted in hepatic failure since it is extensively metabolized in the liver; renal dose adjustment is less critical.

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure: Generally, no dose adjustment is needed in mild to moderate hepatic or renal failure, but caution is advised in severe cases; dose reduction is not routinely required in mild-moderate failure.

 

Option C. The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure: Dose adjustment is usually required in renal impairment; hepatic metabolism is significant but dose reduction is mainly for renal failure, so the statement is incorrect.

choices.text: Janus kinase 2/signal transducers and activators of transcription

questions.text: 66-year-old man with hypertension and stage IV chronic kidney disease comes to the OPD for follow-up. Laboratory results show normocytic, normochromic anemia with a low reticulocyte count. Serum iron studies are within normal limits. Treatment with a recombinant glycoprotein hormone is begun and repeat laboratory testing several weeks later shows an improvement in hemoglobin level. The effects of the hormone prescribed for this patient are most likely mediated by which of the following pathways?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Janus kinase 2/signal transducers and activators of transcription

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has developed persistent food-seeking behavior over the past few months. His mother initially thought that the boy was undergoing a growth spurt, but despite how much she fed him he never seemed satisfied. The patient has also started complaining of a headache and nausea in the morning. His physical examination is significant for BMI of 32 kg/m2.  This patient's food-seeking behavior could be explained by a lesion causing impairment of which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Ventromedial

questions.text: The cardiac output and venous return curves of a healthy person are shown below with solid lines. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the change depicted by the dashed lines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myocardial infarction

 

The dashed lines in the graph show a reduced cardiac output curve (lower plateau) while the venous return curve remains unchanged. This pattern occurs when the heart's pumping efficiency is impaired, but blood volume and venous return capacity are not directly affected. In myocardial infarction, decreased contractility leads to reduced cardiac output, while venous return is initially preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive hydration: Would increase blood volume, shifting the venous return curve upward and to the right, but not primarily reduce cardiac output.

 

Option B. Acute hemorrhage: Would shift the venous return curve downward due to reduced circulating volume, but may not primarily depress the cardiac output plateau unless severe shock occurs.

 

Option C. Chronic anemia: Increases cardiac output due to compensatory mechanisms; it does not depress cardiac function at rest.

choices.text: Binding of triiodothyronine (T3) to its receptors
Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3
Release of T4 by the thyroid gland

questions.text: Propranolol is used in Graves disease. In addition to its beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking activity, this drug is likely to decrease which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

questions.solution: Ans. B) A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

questions.solution: Ans. C. 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-D, 5- C, 6-C

questions.text: 50-year-old man with a remote history of alcohol dependence is evaluated in the clinic for chronic diarrhea and weight loss. The patient has had bloating with daily loose stools for the past 2 years. His stool is described as greasy and malodorous. Pancreatic insufficiency is suspected. The patient undergoes a test in which bicarbonate concentration is measured from duodenal aspirates as hormone A is infused intravenously. The data is plotted in the graph below. Hormone A is produced by?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Duodenal S cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing chest tightness and intermittent sharp chest pains. The patient has no prior chronic medical conditions but had an upper respiratory illness a week ago that resolved without treatment. ECG reveals sinus tachycardia and low voltage QRS complexes that vary in the amplitude from beat to beat. Which of the following is the most likely chest x-ray finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 

 

 

The clinical scenario mentioned here is suggestive of CARDIAC TAMPONADE, shown in image B

 

The patient's presentation of chest tightness and sharp chest pain following an upper respiratory illness, combined with ECG findings of sinus tachycardia and low voltage QRS complexes with beat-to-beat variation in amplitude (electrical alternans), strongly suggests pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade.

 

  • The history of recent upper respiratory illness points to viral pericarditis leading to pericardial effusion.
  • Low voltage QRS complexes reflect fluid insulating the heart.
  • Electrical alternans (variation in QRS amplitude) is classic for large pericardial effusion with the heart swinging inside the fluid.
  • Sinus tachycardia is a compensatory response to reduced cardiac output.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Image A suggests TETROLOGY OF FALLOT, seen in infants.

 

Option C. Image C suggests PERICARDITIS, denoted by inflammatory thickening shown with white ARROW

 

Option D. Image D suggests TAPVC of supracardiac variety{FIGURE OF 8 sign} seen in infancy

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman has been enrolled in a longitudinal research study on aging for the last 30 years. Medical history is significant for osteoporosis; she has developed moderate kyphosis due to gradual loss of vertebral body height. She is otherwise active and healthy with no additional medical issues. She has never smoked. Compared to her physiology testing done years ago, which of the following changes is most consistent with normal aging in 1) lung compliance, 2) total respiratory system compliance and 3) physiologic dead space respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase, decrease, increase

 

With aging, lung compliance increases due to loss of elastic tissue, but total respiratory system compliance decreases because of chest wall stiffening. Physiologic dead space increases due to changes in ventilation-perfusion matching.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase, increase, increase: Incorrect; total respiratory system compliance decreases with age due to chest wall changes.

 

Option C. Increase, unchanged, decrease: Incorrect; total compliance does not remain unchanged and dead space tends to increase.

 

Option D. Decrease, decrease, increase: Incorrect; lung compliance increases, not decreases, with aging.

 

Concept of lung compliance is important in OLD and RLD:

choices.text: Autoantibodies to host cell basement membranes
Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium

questions.text:
A7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for arthralgias. He had a cough and runny nose last week but otherwise has been in good health. Physical examination shows raised, red-purple papules, some of which have coalesced, over the patient's buttocks and thighs. Auscultation of the lungs and heart is normal. The abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds. The knees are tender but do not appear warm or swollen. Urinalysis results are as follows:

 

Protein: 2+

 

Blood: moderate

 

Leukocyte esterase: trace

 

White blood cells: 1-2/hpf

 

Red blood cells (RBCs): many/hpf

 

Casts: RBC casts

 

Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's renal findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of easy fatigability. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly, and his complete blood count shows mild anemia . Hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed at alkaline pH on a cellulose acetate strip. Findings for the patient are shown below compared to individuals with normal hemoglobin and known sickle cell disease. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. HbC disease

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD for treatment of anxiety that has worsened over the past year. She says, "My anxiety just comes out of the blue; one way or another, I'm anxious all the time.  An anxiety disorder is diagnosed, and fluoxetine is prescribed. The patient's anxiety begins to improve over the next 4-6 weeks. The physician explains that the medication inhibits the reuptake of a neurotransmitter released by a specific set of neurons. These neurons are likely part of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Raphe nuclei

 

  • Fluoxetine is an SSRI that increases serotonin levels. Serotonin is primarily produced by the raphe nuclei in the brainstem.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus: Part of the basal ganglia involved in motor control and habit learning, not serotonin production.


Option B. Locus ceruleus: Major site of norepinephrine synthesis, associated with arousal and stress response.


Option C. Nucleus basalis of Meynert: Source of acetylcholine, implicated in memory and cognition, especially in Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Echocardiography shows biventricular dilation and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. After initial stabilization, long-term use of which of the following medications will most likely improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carvedilol

 

Carvedilol is a beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties, shown to improve survival, reduce hospitalization, and improve symptoms in patients with chronic systolic heart failure (low ejection fraction) by decreasing sympathetic nervous system overactivity[guidelines].

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Used to relieve symptoms of fluid overload but does not improve survival.

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker that does not improve survival in systolic heart failure and may worsen outcomes.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Improves symptoms and reduces hospitalizations but does not improve survival.

questions.text: The cells marked in the image of adrenal biopsy are directly activated by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine 

 

The image shows the adrenal medulla, with the arrow indicating chromaffin cells. These cells are directly activated by acetylcholine released from preganglionic sympathetic fibers, leading to secretion of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. ACTH: Stimulates the adrenal cortex, not the medulla.

 

Option C. Angiotensin II: Stimulates aldosterone in the zona glomerulosa of the cortex, not adrenal medulla.

 

Option D. Epinephrine: Is secreted by the adrenal medulla, but does not activate chromaffin cells.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

  1. TxA2 has platelet aggregating and vasoconstricting effect
  2. Lipoxin B4 inhibits inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.
  3. Il-1, Il-18, TNF are pyrogenic cytokines
  4. C3 can be activated is both common as well as alternative pathways

questions.solution: Ans. B. 1, 2, 4, 5

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

  1. Rolapitant is the drug of choice for cisplatin induced intractable vomiting on the third day of treatment.
  2. Filgrastim is the drug of choice for chemotherapy induced thrombocytopenia
  3. Cephalosporins that do not require dose adjustment in renal failure because they are secreted in bile are ceftriaxone and cefoperazone.
  4. Denosumab can decrease bone resorption as well as increase bone formation
questions.solution: Ans. C. 1, 3

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

  1. Flow cytometry is the IOC for CLL
  2. MCL1, BCL-2, BCL-XL and PUMA are anti-apoptotic factors.
  3. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failute have accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.
  4. B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to somatic hypermutation
  5. CD16, CD56 and CD94 are NK cell markers.
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1, 3, 5

questions.text: 62-year-old man comes for the evaluation of jaundice. Medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMl is 47 kg/m2.  Laboratory studies reveal elevated transaminases. A  liver biopsy is obtained, and trichrome staining shows the following. Which of the following cells is directly responsible for the histologic finding indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stellate (Ito) cells

 

  • Hepatic stellate (Ito) cells, located in the space of Disse, normally store vitamin A.
  • In chronic liver injury (eg, NAFLD/NASH, alcohol, hepatitis), stellate cells are activated by cytokines from Kupffer cells → transform into myofibroblast-like cells → secrete collagen → fibrosis/cirrhosis.
  • The trichrome stain highlights collagen deposition = hallmark of fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocytes: Epithelial cells of bile ducts; involved in cholestatic diseases, not fibrosis.

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Undergo ballooning degeneration & necrosis but do not produce collagen directly.

 

Option C. Kupffer cells: Liver macrophages; release cytokines (eg, TGF-β) that activate stellate cells but are not the direct source of fibrosis.

choices.text: Blood loss from hypertrophied pulmonary arteries
Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage due to vasculitis
Formation of a fistula between the tracheobronchial tree and aorta

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to hemoptysis and severe respiratory distress. The patient has been on several oral antibiotics for pneumonia over the past week and has required numerous similar treatments in the past. Pulmonary examination reveals diffusely reduced air flow, rales, and intercostal retractions. Despite aggressive management, the patient ultimately expires. An autopsy is performed and a gross lung specimen is shown in the image below:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's hemoptysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bleeding from hypertrophied bronchial arteries

 

The gross lung specimen reveals extensive cystic changes and dilated airways, consistent with advanced bronchiectasis. In this condition, repeated infections cause hypertrophy of the bronchial arteries, which are the usual source of significant hemoptysis in affected patients.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Blood loss from hypertrophied pulmonary arteries: Pulmonary arteries do not typically hypertrophy or bleed in bronchiectasis; hemoptysis from pulmonary arteries is less common.

 

Option C. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage due to vasculitis: This presents with diffuse infiltrates and is associated with conditions like Goodpasture's or Wegener's, not the cystic bronchiectatic changes seen here.

 

Option D. Formation of a fistula between the tracheobronchial tree and aorta: Extremely rare and would present acutely, not with chronic pulmonary changes.

choices.text: Decreased peritubular capillary oncotic pressure

questions.text: 45-year-old man comes to the office for an annual medical visit. The patient has had prediabetes for the last 2 years. He feels well and takes no medications but has gained weight since his last visit a year ago. The patient has a strong family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg and BMI is 32 kg/m². Laboratory results show a fasting blood glucose of 157 mg/dL and serum creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.4%. Urine assay shows no detectable albuminuria. Which of the following renal changes is most likely present in this patient at this time?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Increased glomerular filtration rate

questions.text: Two antineoplastic drugs are shown to inhibit intracellular thymidylate formation. The chemotherapeutic effect of drug X can be overcome by Ns-formyl-tetrahydrofolate supplementation, but that of drug Y is not affected. The drugs described in this scenario are most likely which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D. X: Methotrexate Y: Fluorouracil

questions.text: 20-year-old, previously healthy woman is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. On arrival at the emergency department, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min. On physical examination, the patient is alert but appearsanxious, pale, and diaphoretic. The lungs are clear bilaterally and cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia.The abdomen is soft. Several actively bleeding lacerations are present on the lower extremities. Which of the following findings are most likely present in this patient in 1) Cardiac contractility, 2) baroreceptor firing and 3)ANP release respectively?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Increases, decreases, increases

choices.text: Diffusely fibrotic marrow with clusters of megakaryocytes
Increased staining for storage iron in marrow macrophages
Marrow replaced by dysplastic cells of all 3 lineages
Severely hypocellular marrow replaced by adipose cells

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the OPD with a few months of severe fatigue and a 6.8-kg unintentional loss in weight. Abdominal examination shows mild hepatomegaly and a markedly enlarged spleen. Stool guaiac testing is negative. Laboratory results show pancytopenia, and peripheral blood smear is shown below. Bone marrow aspiration is attempted but yields no marrow, and a bone marrow biopsy is subsequently performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient's bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffusely fibrotic marrow with clusters of megakaryocytes 

 

  • The patient’s presentation of severe fatigue, weight loss, hepatomegaly, markedly enlarged spleen, pancytopenia, and a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is characteristic of primary myelofibrosis.
  • In primary myelofibrosis, bone marrow biopsy shows diffuse fibrosis with increased reticulin and collagen deposition, often accompanied by clusters of atypical megakaryocytes.
  • The fibrosis leads to marrow failure and extramedullary hematopoiesis, causing splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased staining for storage iron in marrow macrophages: seen in iron overload or sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Marrow replaced by dysplastic cells of all 3 lineages: Seen in myelodysplastic syndromes.

 

Option D. Severely hypocellular marrow replaced by adipose cells: Typical of aplastic anemia.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

  1. Aminophylline acts as an adenosine receptor antagonist leading to diuresis
  2. Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant known to cause priapism
  3. Trofinetide, an analog of glycine-proline-glutamate (GPE), is used to treat cerebral palsy
  4. An orphan drug is a drug that is required for treatment or prevention of a rare disease
questions.solution: Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive, and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

choices.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of chest pain with each episode lasting for 20-30mins and partial response with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He is a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Injection enoxaparin

questions.text: 62-year-old man is hospitalized with severe abdominal pain and diarhea after a recent urinary tract infection.  An appropriate workup confirms C difficile colitis. The patient is placed on an oral macrocyclic antibiotic that inhibits the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase. Which of the following agents was most likely administered to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Fidaxomicin

questions.text: 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset weakness in his right arm and leg. Although he can speak, he cannot pronounce words clearly.  Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength in both right upper and lower extremities. When the patient is asked to stick out his tongue, it deviates to the left. Sensory examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of this patient's brain injury?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Left medial medulla

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is being evaluated for progressive shortness of breath. His respiratory flow-volume curve is shown in red below. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Interalveolar wall destruction

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to generalized edema, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion for 2 months. The patient has a 25-year history of poorly controlled rheumatoid arthritis. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following histologic abnormalities is most likely to be seen in this patient's glomeruli?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deposition of amorphous material

 

Chronic inflammatory conditions (like RA) predispose to secondary amyloidosis with deposition of amorphous, eosinophilic material (amyloid) in glomeruli → nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crescent formation: Seen in RPGN, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Diffuse hypercellularity: Typical of post-streptococcal GN.

 

Option D. IgA deposition: Suggests Berger’s disease (IgA nephropathy).

questions.text:
35-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of weakness, fatigue, and pallor. Physical examination is unremarkable except for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Haemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 fL

 

Reticulocytes: 0.1%

 

Platelets: 280,000 /uL

 

Leukocyte count: 6,700 cells/uL

 

Iron studies and serum B12 and folic acid levels are within normal limits. Bone marrow biopsy shows absence of erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic elements. Further workup would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymic tumor

 

  • The patient has pure red cell aplasia (PRCA), characterized by anemia with low reticulocyte count, normal white blood cells and platelets, and bone marrow showing absent erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic lineages.
  • PRCA can be secondary to thymoma (thymic tumor), an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies or T cells suppress erythroid precursors.
  • Other malignancies listed are not commonly associated with PRCA.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Primarily causes anemia through chronic disease or bleeding but is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia or selective erythroid precursor absence.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma: Known for producing erythropoietin and causing polycythemia rather than anemia; it is not typically linked with isolated red cell aplasia.

 

Option D. Cerebellar hemangioblastoma: Associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease and can lead to polycythemia due to ectopic erythropoietin production, not isolated anemia or red cell aplasia.

 

The image below shows THYMUS TUMOR on CT [likely suggestive of THYMOMA]

choices.text: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus
Degeneration of the spinocerebellar tracts

questions.text: 5-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother due to difficulty with movement. The patient enjoys playing high school basketball but had to leave the team this year due to his progressively worsening symptoms On examination, he is found to have significant kyphoscoliosis. Image of the patient’s feet are shown below. His older brother suffered from a neurologic disorder and died of heart failure at age 25. This patient most likely has which of the following neuropathologic findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Degeneration of the spinocerebellar tracts

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is referred to a cardiologist after heart murmur is discovered during a routine checkup. The patient is healthy and has no symptoms.  She runs daily and wants to start actively training for a half marathon.  Auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by a short late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. The murmur disappears with squatting.What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Mitral valve prolapse

questions.text: 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a severe, sudden-onset headache with loss of vision in bilateral temporal fields that started an hour ago. The patient reports that he has had mild headaches and decreased libido over the past 3 months.  Shortly after being admitted to the hospital, he becomes acutely hypotensive and loses consciousness. Which of the following is most likely to be found on autopsy?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland

questions.text: 64-year-old man is evaluated for persistent fever and weakness. He has a history of aortic valve replacement for aortic stenosis. Physical examination reveals a new cardiac murmur with scattered petechiae, and splinter hemorrhages seen on his extremities. Echocardiogram shows a vegetation involving one of the aortic valve leaflets, and blood cultures grow enterococci. As part of the patient's treatment, 240 mg of intravenous gentamicin is started. The pharmacy calculates that, in this patient, gentamicin has a volume of distribution of 30litres, a half-life of 4 hours, and demonstrates first-order and one-compartment kinetics. Which of the following is the most likely serum drug concentration just before the next dose 8 hours later?
questions.solution: Ans. D) 2 mg/L

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High

 

Recent surgery and unilateral leg swelling contribute significantly to the Well’s score, placing the patient at high risk for pulmonary embolism even without other symptoms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Low: Incorrect; postoperative leg swelling increases risk.

 

Option C. Moderate: Risk is higher due to surgery and symptoms.

 

Option D. Cannot comment without d-dimer values: Well’s score risk stratification does not require d-dimer for initial assessment.

 

Wells Score for Pulmonary Embolism

 

 

Interpretation

 

  • Low Risk: < 2 points
  • Intermediate Risk: 2–6 points
  • High Risk: > 6 points
  • PE unlikely: 0–4 points
  • PE likely: > 4 points

choices.text: Had an accidental needlestick exposure at work
Had steamed oysters at a neighborhood restaurant
Had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner

questions.text:
34-year-old woman comes to the OPD with recent onset of malaise. The patient works as a nurse at a local hospital and lives at home with her husband and 2-year-old son.  Physical examination is notable for hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:

Anti-HAV IgM Positive

Anti-HAV IgG negative

HBsAg negative

HBeAg negative

Anti-HBs positive

Anti-HBc negative

Anti-HBe negative

Anti-HCV negative

Which of the following is most likely to be elicited on further history taking?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Had steamed oysters at a neighborhood restaurant


Acute HAV infection is indicated by anti-HAV IgM positive (with IgG negative). Hepatitis A spreads fecal–orally, classically from contaminated shellfish (e.g., oysters) or food/water outbreaks. Her HBV panel (isolated anti-HBs positive with negative anti-HBc) is consistent with immunity due to vaccination, and HCV is negative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Had an accidental needlestick exposure at work: Parenteral risk for HBV/HCV, not HAV; her serology shows no acute HBV/HCV.

 

Option B. Had a blood transfusion: Transfusion-transmitted viral hepatitis is typically HCV/HBV; HAV is not blood-borne.

 

Option D. Had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner: Sexual transmission is key for HBV; HAV is primarily fecal–oral and her HBV panel shows vaccine immunity.

questions.text: 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple burns on her hands. She says that she gets burned quite often when she cooks, particularly while operating the oven. She also has burned herself when picking up her morning cup of coffee and when testing the water temperature in the shower. The patient s concerned because she cannot feel when objects are "really hot" and often does not notice that she has burns until she looks at her hands.  Her family history is significant for multiple sclerosis in her mother. Examination shows diminished pinprick and temperature sensation across the upper back, shoulders, and arms bilaterally. Light touch, position, and vibration sense are preserved. Examination of the lower extremities is unremarkable. Damage to which of the following spinal cord areas is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A. A

questions.text: 37-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive shortness of breath and dry cough. The patient has seasonal allergies and takes no medications. Chest imaging studies reveal pulmonary infiltrates and hilar adenopathy. The patient undergoes lung biopsy; the findings are shown below. Which of the following sets of immune cells and cytokines is most likely responsible for the development of this patient's pathologic findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Th1, lL-2, interferon-ƴ

questions.text:
21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to diffuse muscle aches and weakness. He has also noticed darkening of his urine. The patient recently joined the military and was participating in rigorous training exercises in hot weather earlier in the day. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 136 mEq/L

 

Potassium: 5.6 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 18 mEq/L

 

Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL

 

CK: 22,000 U/L (normal: 30-170)

 

Which of the following urine microscopy is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granular casts

 

This is rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis (ATN) → dark urine (myoglobinuria), hyperkalemia, high CK. ATN commonly shows granular (“muddy brown”) casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysmorphic RBCs: Seen in glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Eosinophils: Seen in allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Option D. Waxy casts: Seen in chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: 35-year-old man is being evaluated for nontender cervical lymphadenopathy that he first noticed while shaving. A biopsy is performed, histology is shown below. Cytogenetic analysis would most likely demonstrate which of the following patterns?
questions.solution: Ans. A) BCL-2 overexpression

questions.text: 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after he develops dificulty speaking. When asked about the onset of his symptoms, the patient slowly responds with "weak... morning..." and becomes very frustrated. On examination, he is able to state his first name but with difficulty, and correctly points to different body parts on command. This patient's speech difficulties are most likely caused by a lesion affecting which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

  • Broca’s aphasia is classically caused by infarction of the territory supplied by the left MCA, [LEFT is the dominant hemisphere ]particularly its superior division.
  • The examination findings (non-fluent speech, good comprehension, frustration) confirm Broca’s (expressive) aphasia, which is supplied by D in this image.

 

  • A and B: These arrows point to the Anterior Cerebral Arteries (ACA), specifically showing the A1 segments before they merge to form the anterior communicating artery.
  • C: This arrow indicates the Right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA), a major artery supplying blood to large parts of the brain.
  • D: This arrow points to a left Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) on the opposite side.
  • E: This arrow indicates the Basilar Artery, formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries, and located at the base of the brain

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of mitral stenosis comes to the OPD. Cardiac auscultation reveals an opening snap and a rumbling murmur heard best in the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Timing of these sounds  best corresponds to which of the following letters?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The opening snap in mitral stenosis occurs shortly after the mitral valve opens, which happens at the beginning of diastole, just as left ventricular pressure falls below left atrial pressure. On the pressure tracing, this corresponds to point C, where the left atrial pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure and the mitral valve opens, producing the opening snap heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A, B, D, E: These points do not match the precise moment after mitral valve opening; they relate to other phases (A: early systole,
  •  B: aortic valve opening,
  •  D: aortic closure, 
  •  E: just after systole).

 

Thus, timing of the opening snap best corresponds to C on the pressure tracing.

choices.text: Drug 1 has lower potency than Drug 2
Drug 2 has higher affinity for alpha-receptors than Drug 3
Drug 1 demonstrates the highest efficacy
Drug 2 and Drug 3 bind to different loci of alpha-receptors

questions.text:
Three alpha-agonist drugs are tested as potential vasoconstrictors. The degree of vasoconstriction is determined by measuring the cross-sectional area of an isolated vessel after application of the drug. The following curves are obtained:

 

 

Which of the following is the best statement concerning the effects of these drugs?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Drug 2 has higher affinity for alpha-receptors than Drug 3

questions.text: 44-year-old woman comes to the office due to a breast mass. Physical examination reveals a hard, fixed mass in the right breast with palpable ipsilateral axillary lymphadenopathy.  The ability of the tumor to reach the draining lymph nodes is facilitated by which of the following changes at the primary tumor site?

questions.text: A 4-week-old, full-term boy is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting. His parents describe the emesis as undigested formula without blood or bile. The vomiting occurs after feeds and has increased in frequency and force over the past 3 days. Examination shows a sunken anterior fontanelle and dry mucous membranes. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following sets of values?
questions.solution: Ans. C) pH 7.48, PaCo2 46, HCO3 34, Anion gap normal

questions.text: 6-year-old girl is brought to the office due to intermittent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for 2 months.  Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Which of the following locations should be biopsied to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Duodenum

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent transient pulmonary infiltrates. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma and has had several exacerbations over the past few years, particularly during the winter months. Her medications include albuterol as needed and medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoids. Complete blood count shows eosinophilia. A chest CT scan reveals proximal bronchiectasis. This patient's condition is most likely related to colonization with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) occurs in asthmatics and causes proximal bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and recurrent infiltrates due to hypersensitivity to Aspergillus colonization.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adenovirus: Not typically associated with bronchiectasis or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Strongyloides: Causes eosinophilia but not bronchiectasis or recurrent infiltrates.

 

Option D. Paragonimus: Can cause pulmonary symptoms but not characteristic proximal bronchiectasis.

questions.text: 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting blood. After appropriate resuscitation measures, he undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, which reveals a bleeding duodenal ulcer. During hospital day 2, the patient develops decreased urine output. Serum creatinine rises to 3.0 mg/dL from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL. Renal biopsy shows patchy epithelial necrosis of the tubules, intratubular casts. Supportive care is provided. Several days later, his urine output significantly increases, and serum creatinine levels decline. Over the next few days, this patient is at highest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia

 

During recovery phase of ATN, patients develop polyuria due to impaired tubular reabsorption. This causes massive potassium loss → hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Seen in initial oliguric phase, not recovery phase.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: More likely in maintenance phase.

 

Option D. Volume overload: Occurs in oliguric phase, not diuretic recovery phase.

questions.text: 26-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 8 weeks gestation comes to the OPDdue to pain and swelling of her left leg for the past day. The patient had a pulmonary embolism during her previous pregnancy, and prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin therapy was initiated 6 days ago.  Venous duplex ultrasonography reveals acute left femoral vein thrombosis. Platelet count, which was normal prior to anticoagulant therapy initiation, is now 84,000/mm3. Other blood cell counts and renal and liver function studies are within normal limits. Which of the following most likely predisposed this patient to her current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Anti-platelet factor 4 antibodies

questions.text: 82-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to memory loss. She lives with her daughter, who reports that her mother has had difficulty remembering recent conversations. The patient has also forgotten recent events, such as her grandson's birthday party last month. Two years ago, she was forced to give up driving after repeatedly getting lost in her own neighborhood and being involved in a minor motor vehicle accident. Which of the following is the most likely pathological finding in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest tightness that started 30 minutes prior to arrival. He has 2 histories of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Initial ECG Shows ST elevation in leads I and aVL. Cardiac enzymes are elevated. Emergent cardiac catheterization in this patient will most likely show occlusion of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Left circumflex artery

questions.text: 51-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to progressively worsening fatigue, weight gain, and constipation for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows mild, diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland.  Biopsy of this patient's thyroid is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The patients condition is likely suggestive of Hashimoto thyroiditis denoted by option A and symptoms of hypothyroidism such WEIGHT GAIN , CONSTIPATION Ahave been mentioned in the question.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Is Medullary CA thyroid

 

Option C. Suggestive of papillary Ca thyroid

 

Option D. Suggests Amyloidosis inside thyroid
