questions.solution: Ans. A. Metformin

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG is shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Epinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following is a Pre-protein Convertin Subtilisin Kexin type 9 inhibitor?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Evolocumab

choices.text: Chromaffin cells of the adrenals
Juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney
Zona glomerulosa of the adrenals

questions.text: 27-year-old man comes to the OPD due to recurrent episodes of muscle weakness.  His blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg supine and 195/110 mm Hg standing. His heart rate is 70/min supine and 72/min standing. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Laboratory evaluation shows very low plasma renin activity. Overactivity of which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Zona glomerulosa of the adrenals

questions.text: Which of the following would be the expected physical examination finding over the right lower chest?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreased tactile fremitus

choices.text: Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, normal 1,25 hydroxyVitD
Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD
High serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, low PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD
Low serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD

questions.text: 56-year-old man with chronic renal insufficiency due to polycystic kidney disease is evaluated for placement of an arteriovenous fistula for dialysis access. Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. Examination shows 2+ bilateral edema of the lower extremities. Estimated glomerular filtration rate is 15 mL/min/1.73 m². Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD

 

This is secondary hyperparathyroidism due to CKD. Diseased kidneys cannot excrete phosphorus (→ ↑ phosphorus), and cannot activate vitamin D (→ ↓ 1,25 VitD), causing hypocalcemia and compensatory ↑ PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, normal 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Wrong, it’s low in CKD.

 

Option C. Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Suggests hypercalcemia of malignancy, not CKD.

 

Option D. Low serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Not seen in CKD; phosphorus retention causes hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with sudden-onset abdominal pain and ascites. Laboratory studies show anemia, reticulocytosis, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Flow cytometry of the patient's peripheral blood cells using the appropriate monoclonal antibodies is shown. CT scan of the abdomen shows hepatic vein thrombosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Complement activation

choices.text: Enhancing the effect of endogenous dopamine

questions.text: 72-year-old man with a history of Parkinson disease comes to the OPD for follow-up. The patient has been taking carbidopa-levodopa since being diagnosed 5 years ago and has required increasing doses to control his symptoms. He is now taking the maximum dose but  reports worsening stiffness and difficulty moving between his scheduled doses; these symptoms improve after he takes the medication. Entacapone is added to his treatment regimen. This drug is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreasing peripheral levodopa degradation

 

The symptoms described represent “wearing-off” phenomena in Parkinson’s disease treated with carbidopa-levodopa. Adding entacapone improves symptoms by:

 

Decreasing peripheral levodopa degradation

 

  • Entacapone is a COMT (catechol-O-methyltransferase) inhibitor, which inhibits the peripheral breakdown of levodopa into inactive metabolites, thereby increasing its availability to the brain.
  • This leads to more stable and prolonged plasma levodopa levels, reducing motor fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Directly stimulating dopamine receptors: Direct dopamine receptor stimulation is the effect of dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole), not entacapone.

 

Option C. Enhancing the effect of endogenous dopamine: Enhancing endogenous dopamine action is indirect and vague; entacapone acts by inhibiting levodopa degradation.

 

Option D. Inhibiting central muscarinic receptors: Central muscarinic receptor inhibition is the mechanism of anticholinergics, unrelated to entacapone.

questions.text: 78-year-old man dies of advanced esophageal cancer. On microscopic examination, myocardial cells demonstrate prominent yellow-brown intracytoplasmic granules as shown. Which of the following most likely accounts for the observed microscopic changes?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Lipid peroxidation

questions.text: Autopsy is being performed on a 72-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction. Light microscopy of a portion of the left ventricle reveals the findings shown in the image below. This patient most likely sustained the myocardial infarction during which of the following time frames prior to his death?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1 to 3 days

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been experiencing visual changes, including blurry vision and halos around lights. She has been on medication for her rheumatoid arthritis for a couple of years now. Which of the following drugs she might be taking is known to get deposited in the cornea?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Chloroquine

questions.text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Streptococcus.

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dl and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

 

  • Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist.
  • By blocking V2 receptors in the collecting duct, water reabsorption is reduced, leading to aquaresis (excretion of free water without electrolyte loss).
  • This results in polyuria, thirst, and dry mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 receptor agonism: Opposite effect; would decrease urine output.

 

Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels: Tolvaptan actually reduces cAMP-mediated cyst growth, not responsible for thirst.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolality: Tolvaptan decreases urine osmolality due to water loss.

 

Key point: Tolvaptan causes aquaresis → increased free water clearance → thirst and dry mouth.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital due to perforated appendicitis. The patient quickly develops respiratory difficulty, and acute respiratory distress syndrome is diagnosed. She is intubated and mechanically ventilated with positive pressure ventilation. She is intermittently placed in the prone position while mechanically ventilated. Which of the following is most likely to occur due to this position change?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Improved ventilation-perfusion matching

 

Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, improving oxygenation by reducing lung compression and enhancing ventilation-perfusion matching in ARDS patients.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Alveolar hyperdistention: Not typically associated with prone positioning; often minimized by lung-protective ventilation.

 

Option B. Decreased cardiac output: May occur but is generally outweighed by oxygenation benefits.

 

Option C. Decreased functional residual capacity: Prone position tends to maintain or improve functional residual capacity.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old term boy is brought to the OPD due to increased fussiness and poor weight gain. The patient has several wet diapers per day. His anterior fontanelle is flat and mucous membranes are dry. Laboratory results include the following:

 

Sodium: 148 mEq/L

 

Potassium: 3.5 mEq/L

 

Antidiuretic hormone: increased

 

Urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.002. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide
 

The patient has nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, indicated by hypernatremia, dilute urine, and elevated ADH. Hydrochlorothiazide reduces urine output by inducing mild volume depletion and enhancing proximal tubular water reabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmopressin: Desmopressin is ineffective in nephrogenic DI.

 

Option C. Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone is not indicated.

 

Option D. Insulin: Insulin is unrelated to this condition.

questions.text: Supravital stain of a peripheral smear of a patient is shown. What is the likely inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X-linked recessive inheritance 

 

The image shows a red blood cell with a blue-stained inclusion, most likely a Heinz body, seen with supravital staining. Heinz bodies suggest underlying G6PD deficiency, which leads to the formation of these inclusions when red cells are under oxidative stress.

 

G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

choices.text: Glucose normal, protein increased, cells increased (RBC)
Glucose low, protein increased, cells increased (neutrophils)
Glucose normal, protein increased, cells increased (lymphocytes, RBC)
Glucose low,  protein decreased, cells increased (lymphocytes)

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His roommate says that the patient has had a fever and headache for the past 2 days and that today he was talking nonsensically.  MRI of the brain shows swelling of the temporal lobes. CSF analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following patterns?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Glucose normal, protein increased, cells increased (lymphocytes, RBC)

questions.text: 69-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a 6-month history of chest tightness when he walks uphill or climbs stairs. Cardiac examination reveals no murmurs or additional heart sounds. The patient is prescribed a medication that is metabolized to S-nitroso thiols in the vascular smooth muscle cells, and he reports rapid and significant symptom relief. Which of the following components of the cardiovascular system is most susceptible to the medication prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Large veins

questions.text: 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD for progressive itchiness and fatigue. She also notes yellowing of the eyes and skin. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, multiple excoriations on both the upper and the lower extremities, and hepatomegaly.  Liver biopsy reveals dense lymphocytic infiltration of the portal triads, as well. as granulomatous destruction of intralobular bile ducts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. PBC

questions.text:
44-year-old man reports exertional shortness of breath and palpitations. On examination, he has a systolic murmur at the left sternal border and cardiac apex, which gets louder when he stands up. He is diagnosed with obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and is started on a medication. Changes in the action potential of ventricular muscle cells before and after administration of medication are shown in the image below. The patient is most likely being treated with which of the following medications?

 

 

The patient is most likely being treated with which of the following medications?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Disopyramide

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented in OPD with recurrent respiratory infections and thickened sputum. Chest X-ray is shown. Patient also had steatorrhea since birth. What is the likely defect?
questions.solution: Ans. A. F508 Deletion

questions.text: Gaisböck syndrome includes all except?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hypotension

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is admitted for fever, cough, and malaise for the past two days. She has no history of sick contacts, and all her immunizations are up to date. Her leukocyte count is 21,000/mm with 7% band forms. Upright chest x-ray findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely location of the pathologic process in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right upper lobe 

 

The upright lateral chest x-ray demonstrates loss of normal translucency in the right upper lobe. The consolidation and opacification seen here, especially in the upper region of the lung on lateral projection, is most consistent with pneumonia affecting the right upper lobe.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Left lower lung lobe: The opacity is not localized to the left lower lobe; the left lung appears relatively clear in this view.

 

Option B. Left pleural space: There is no evidence of pleural fluid or a pleural-based abnormality on the left side.

 

Option C. Right middle lung lobe: The middle lobe occupies a different area on lateral film and would not cause this upper zone opacity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with new-onset confusion and lethargy The changes in his blood gas parameters are shown in the graph below. Point A represents these parameters at the patient's physiologic baseline, and point B indicates his state on arrival in the emergency department. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was playing soccer when he suddenly collapsed. Despite all attempts to save his life, he died. Autopsy is performed. Gross examination of the heart  is shown in the image. If this patient had a preparticipation sports screening, cardiac auscultation would have likely revealed a murmur that increases in intensity after which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Sudden standing

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking presented with fever, confusion, diarrhea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. Gram stain, immunofluorescence testing was done on sputum sample and came negative for organisms. Serology findings are given below. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this presentation?

 

Serum Na+ – 120 meq/L

 

AST – 62 IU/L

 

ALT – 56 IU/L

 

HIV – Positive
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

 Diagnosis from Clinical Clues:

 

  • Elderly chronic smoker → high risk for atypical pneumonia.
  • Symptoms: fever, confusion, diarrhoea, cough → classic for Legionnaires’ disease.
  • Chest X-ray: bilateral infiltrates.
  • Lab findings:
    • Hyponatremia (Na+ 120) → hallmark feature of Legionella.
    • Mildly elevated AST/ALT → commonly seen.
  • HIV positive → immunocompromised host, poses further risk.
  • Sputum stain & culture negative → Legionella does not grow on standard media; requires BCYE agar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus (S. pneumoniae): 

 

  • Causes lobar pneumonia with productive cough and positive Gram stain (Gram-positive diplococci).
  • Does not cause hyponatremia or diarrhoea.

 

Option C. Klebsiella:

 

  • Causes currant-jelly sputum, mainly in alcoholics and diabetics.
  • Shows Gram-negative bacilli on stain; not negative like here.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis carinii (jirovecii) pneumonia:

 

  • Common in HIV patients with CD4 <200.
  • Presents with subacute dyspnoea, dry cough, hypoxemia; CXR shows ground-glass opacities, not diarrhoea or hyponatremia.

questions.text: A patient is receiving chemotherapy with platinum compounds. Which of the following drugs are used for treatment of chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Granisetron, dexamethasone and aprepitant

 

Granisetron + dexamethasone+ aprepitant is used to treat Chemotherapy-induced Nausea and Vomiting.

questions.text: 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a large, painful skin lesion. He does not remember sustaining any trauma. He was recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, for which warfarin was begun. The patient noticed the lesion about 36 hours after starting the medication. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Protein C deficiency

questions.text: 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to seizures. He has had 2 days of worsening fever, headache, and vomiting. Physical examination shows signs of meningeal irritation. The patient rapidly becomes comatose and dies 48 hours later despite aggressive medical care. Autopsy examination shows congested leptomeninges with fibrinopurulent exudate. Microscopy reveals numerous ameba in the exudate and brain  tissue. Which of the following is the most likely portal of entry of this pathogen into the CNS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E

 

The most likely portal of entry of the pathogen in this scenario is the cribriform plate (E), corresponding to the site labeled "E" in the image, which is where Naegleria fowleri (an ameba causing primary amebic meningoencephalitis) typically enters the CNS via the olfactory nerve after inhalation of contaminated water.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • The patient presents with rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis leading to death, and autopsy reveals amebae in the brain tissue, most consistent with Naegleria fowleri infection.
  • The usual portal for this amoeba is via the nasal mucosa, entering through the cribriform plate to reach the CNS.

 

Brain Anatomy Identified

 

  • A: Brainstem
  • B: Basilar artery
  • C: Oculomotor nerve
  • D: Optic chiasma
  • E: Cribriform plate region (where the olfactory nerves pass through)

questions.text: Following graph shows response of a drug, identify the drug?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Norepinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of ABPA?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Distal bronchiectasis

A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital
A patient who was brought dead to the hospital
A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

questions.text: Which of the following patients comes under the category III non-heart-beating donor?
questions.solution: Ans. D. A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

questions.text: 54-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a neck mass that has been slowly growing over the past 3 months.  He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years and has used alcohol occasionally. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm, hard, left-sided supraclavicular lymph node. Biopsy of the lymph node reveals anaplastic cells that are diffusely positive for cytokeratin immunohistochemical stain. Which of the following is the most likely origin of the cells detected on the biopsy?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Epithelial cells

questions.text: 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to chest palpitations The patient feels that his heartbeat is fast and irregular. The patient normally drinks only 2-3 times a year, but he hosted a party last night for his wife's birthday and consumed a large amount of alcohol. Pulse check confirms the presence of an irregularly irregular rhythm with a rate of 138/min. This patient's ECG strip is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B.
